A subset is a set where all of its elements are also contained within another set.
A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).
The domain of a function is the set of all possible input values for which the function is defined. Every input value in the domain has a corresponding output in the codomain via the function.
The codomain of a function is the set that contains all potential output values, even if some of those values are not actually produced by any input in the domain.
A tensor is a multi-dimensional array, generalizing the concept of a scalar, vector and matrix.
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
The kernel of \( f \) is defined as:\[\mathrm{Ker}(f) = \{ a \in A \mid f(a) = 0 \} and is hence a subset of the Domain A.\]

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A subset is a specialization of a set, as it inherits all properties of being a set but with the additional constraint that all its elements are also elements of another specific set.
The domain of a function is a specialization of a set, as it consists of all possible input values for the function, which are distinct objects considered as an entity.
The codomain of a function is a specialization of a set, as it consists of all potential output values for the function, which are distinct objects considered as an entity.
The image of a map is a specialization of a set, as it consists of all elements in the codomain that have at least one corresponding element in the domain via the function.
The kernel of a map is a specialization of a set, as it consists of all elements in the domain for which the function outputs zero, and these elements are distinct objects considered as an entity.
